keyTakeAways: Colombia has recalled its ambassador to the United States for consultations, signaling a major diplomatic escalation over drug trafficking and U.S. military actions.
The recall follows a previous incident in July when the U.S. recalled its ambassador to Bogotá, highlighting a recurring pattern of mutual diplomatic retaliation.
U.S. President Donald Trump accused President Gustavo Petro of being a 'drug leader' and threatened to cut subsidies and raise tariffs on Colombian goods.
The U.S. has deployed warships in the Caribbean and launched missile attacks on vessels allegedly involved in drug trafficking, resulting in at least 30 deaths, including some Colombians.
Colombia claims that several individuals on board attacked vessels were Colombian citizens, accusing the U.S. of targeting its nationals and committing acts of murder.
A Colombian citizen aboard the most recent vessel was returned safely to Colombia, suggesting the U.S. operations have had human consequences with potential humanitarian implications.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Colombia has recalled its ambassador to the United States, Daniel García-Peña, for consultations, escalating diplomatic tensions following accusations from U.S. President Donald Trump that Colombian President Gustavo Petro promotes drug production. The move follows a prior recall in July when the U.S. recalled its ambassador to Bogotá. The conflict has intensified with U.S. military operations in the Caribbean, including missile attacks on vessels allegedly involved in drug trafficking, resulting in at least 30 deaths, some of whom are believed to be Colombian nationals. Colombia has accused the U.S. of targeting its citizens and committing acts of murder, while Trump has threatened to cut subsidies and raise tariffs on Colombian exports. This reflects a broader crisis in bilateral relations rooted in drug policy, national sovereignty, and political accusations.
